document: Software Evolution and Maintenance (Chapter 7: Refactoring) by Tripathy & Naik

questions.question: As software evolves, its maintenance cost typically increases. [cite: 32]
Software restructuring is an informal process of adding new requirements to a program. [cite: 74]
Out-of-date documentation is one of the causes for decreased understandability in software. [cite: 33, 35]
External software value refers to the fact that customers view fewer faults as better software. [cite: 51]
A well-structured system is more expensive to maintain than a poorly structured one. [cite: 52]
One simple example of restructuring is using meaningful names for variables. [cite: 55]
Restructuring generally produces a program in a different programming language than the original. [cite: 75]
The first activity in a refactoring process is to identify what needs to be refactored. [cite: 84]
A 'code smell' is a symptom in source code that may indicate a deeper problem. [cite: 108]
Short methods and small classes are listed as examples of code smells. [cite: 112, 113]
Refactoring can be applied to design documents and requirements documents, not just source code. [cite: 101, 103, 104]
Refactoring R1 and R2 (renaming methods in PrintServer and FileServer) must be performed together. [cite: 126]
Refactoring R7 involves exposing a private field so other classes can access it directly. [cite: 130]
In the refactoring process, it is important to ensure that behavior is preserved. [cite: 87]
The order in which refactorings are applied never affects the outcome. [cite: 173]
Refactorings R1 and R2 must precede R3. [cite: 174]
Refactorings R4 and R6 are mutually exclusive. [cite: 179]
Pretty printing is considered a simple example of software restructuring. [cite: 54]
The objective of refactoring is to change the external behavior of the software for the user. [cite: 73, 74]
Software restructuring can help in keeping pace with new software structures. [cite: 59]
